baseline_zero_shot: The Watergate scandal was a major political scandal that arose from the break-in by five men at the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate office complex in Washington, D.C., on June 17, 1972, and President Richard Nixon's administration's subsequent attempts to cover up its involvement. Following extensive investigations, it was revealed that this act was part of a broader pattern of abuses of power by the Nixon administration, which included bribery and obstruction of justice. The scandal ultimately led to the resignation of President Nixon on August 9, 1974, to avoid impeachment.

query: What effects did the Watergate scandal have on President Nixon's legacy?
passage: ["Stephen Lovekin/Getty Images Later in life Nixon's reputation was rehabilitated, as his roles in helping the civil rights movement and opening diplomatic channels between the West, Soviet Russia and Mao's China, were acknowledged and praised. Before his death in 1994, Nixon was acknowledged by many as a respected elder statesman, rather than a criminal.  David McNew/Getty Images Share More", "Nixon had won reelection in 1972 by a landslide and began his second term with a lofty 68% Gallup Poll approval rating in January 1973. But the Watergate scandal – which started with an effort to bug the Democratic National Committee office at the Watergate Hotel and subsequent efforts to cover it up – quickly took a heavy toll on those ratings, especially when coupled with a ramp-up in public concerns about inflation.  By April, a resounding 83% of the American public had heard or read about Watergate, as the president accepted the resignations of his top aides John Ehrlichman and H.R. Haldeman.  And in turn, Nixon's approval ratings fell to 48%.  But that was just the beginning of the toll the scandal would take on the president that year.  The televised Watergate hearings that began in May 1973, chaired by Sen. Samuel Ervin, commanded a large national audience – 71% told Gallup they watched the hearings live.  And as many as 21% reported watching 10 hours or more of the Ervin proceedings.  Not too surprisingly, Nixon's popularity took a severe hit.  His ratings fell as low as 31%, in Gallup's early August survey.  The public had changed its view of the scandal.", "Nixon's onetime opponent George McGovern commented in 1983, 'President Nixon probably had a more practical approach to the two superpowers, China and the Soviet Union, than any other president since World War II [ ...]  With the exception of his inexcusable continuation of the war in Vietnam, Nixon really will get high marks in history.'  Political scientist Jussi Hanhimäki disagrees, saying that Nixon's diplomacy was merely a continuation of the Cold War policy of containment by diplomatic, rather than military means.  Historian Keith W. Olson has written that Nixon left a legacy of fundamental mistrust of government, rooted in Vietnam and Watergate.  Another legacy, for a time, was a decrease in the power of the presidency as Congress passed restrictive legislation like the War Powers Act and the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974.   Section::::Further reading.   BULLET::::- Dallek, Robert, 'Nixon and Kissinger: Partners in Power'.  HarperCollins, 2007.   BULLET::::- Garrison, Jean A. 'Games Advisors Play: Foreign Policy in the Nixon and Carter Administrations' (1999) online  BULLET::::- Graff, Henry F., ed.  'The Presidents: A Reference History' (3rd ed.  2002)  BULLET::::- Hanhimäki, Jussi."]

clusters_summaries: ["The Watergate scandal severely tarnished President Nixon's legacy, leading to widespread public awareness and interest, and ultimately his resignation.", "The Watergate scandal severely damaged President Nixon's legacy by causing his approval ratings to plummet to as low as 31%.", "The Watergate scandal tarnished President Nixon's legacy by decreasing the power of the presidency, though his reputation was somewhat rehabilitated before his death in 1994."]
clusters_based_response: The Watergate scandal severely tarnished President Nixon's legacy, leading to widespread public awareness and interest, and ultimately his resignation. The Watergate scandal severely damaged President Nixon's legacy by causing his approval ratings to plummet to as low as 31%. The Watergate scandal tarnished President Nixon's legacy by decreasing the power of the presidency, though his reputation was somewhat rehabilitated before his death in 1994.

source: ["[1] Stephen Lovekin/Getty Images Later in life Nixon's reputation was rehabilitated, as his roles in helping the civil rights movement and opening diplomatic channels between the West, Soviet Russia and Mao's China, were acknowledged and praised. Before his death in 1994, Nixon was acknowledged by many as a respected elder statesman, rather than a criminal.  David McNew/Getty Images Share More", "[2] Nixon had won reelection in 1972 by a landslide and began his second term with a lofty 68% Gallup Poll approval rating in January 1973. But the Watergate scandal – which started with an effort to bug the Democratic National Committee office at the Watergate Hotel and subsequent efforts to cover it up – quickly took a heavy toll on those ratings, especially when coupled with a ramp-up in public concerns about inflation.  By April, a resounding 83% of the American public had heard or read about Watergate, as the president accepted the resignations of his top aides John Ehrlichman and H.R. Haldeman.  And in turn, Nixon's approval ratings fell to 48%.  But that was just the beginning of the toll the scandal would take on the president that year.  The televised Watergate hearings that began in May 1973, chaired by Sen. Samuel Ervin, commanded a large national audience – 71% told Gallup they watched the hearings live.  And as many as 21% reported watching 10 hours or more of the Ervin proceedings.  Not too surprisingly, Nixon's popularity took a severe hit.  His ratings fell as low as 31%, in Gallup's early August survey.  The public had changed its view of the scandal.", "[3] Nixon's onetime opponent George McGovern commented in 1983, 'President Nixon probably had a more practical approach to the two superpowers, China and the Soviet Union, than any other president since World War II [ ...]  With the exception of his inexcusable continuation of the war in Vietnam, Nixon really will get high marks in history.'  Political scientist Jussi Hanhimäki disagrees, saying that Nixon's diplomacy was merely a continuation of the Cold War policy of containment by diplomatic, rather than military means.  Historian Keith W. Olson has written that Nixon left a legacy of fundamental mistrust of government, rooted in Vietnam and Watergate.  Another legacy, for a time, was a decrease in the power of the presidency as Congress passed restrictive legislation like the War Powers Act and the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974.   Section::::Further reading.   BULLET::::- Dallek, Robert, 'Nixon and Kissinger: Partners in Power'.  HarperCollins, 2007.   BULLET::::- Garrison, Jean A. 'Games Advisors Play: Foreign Policy in the Nixon and Carter Administrations' (1999) online  BULLET::::- Graff, Henry F., ed.  'The Presidents: A Reference History' (3rd ed.  2002)  BULLET::::- Hanhimäki, Jussi."]
following_clusters: Nixon left a legacy of fundamental mistrust of government; Congress passed restrictive legislation like the War Powers Act and the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974
single_aspect_responses: The Watergate scandal profoundly impacted President Nixon's legacy, leading to a significant loss of trust and credibility. The public resignations of his top aides and the extensive media coverage, including televised hearings watched by a substantial portion of the American populace, underscored the severity of the scandal. Nixon's association with the events of Watergate and the Vietnam War ultimately marred his presidency, overshadowing his prior achievements and contributing to his resignation under the threat of impeachment.

baseline_zero_shot: The Watergate scandal significantly marred President Nixon's legacy by exposing him to severe political damage and public mistrust. His initially high approval ratings plummeted as the scandal unfolded, evidenced by detailed coverage and the televised Senate Watergate hearings, which were watched by a majority of the American public. Despite some rehabilitation in later years highlighting his diplomatic achievements and civil rights efforts, his presidency is often remembered for the scandal, leading to fundamental mistrust in government and reduced presidential power due to subsequent legislative changes.
rephrased_clusters_based_response: The Watergate scandal significantly marred President Nixon's legacy, resulting in heightened public interest and eventually his resignation. It drastically affected his legacy by driving his approval ratings down to a low of 31%. Additionally, the scandal diminished the power of the presidency, but Nixon’s reputation saw some restoration before he passed away in 1994.

[2] Additionally, the scandal diminished the power of the presidency, but Nixon’s reputation saw some restoration before he passed away in 1994. [1, 3]
